front.title: Oblivious DNS - Strong Privacy for DNS Queries

abstract.t: Recognizing the privacy vulnerabilities associated with DNS queries, a number of standards have been developed and services deployed that that encrypt a user’s DNS queries to the recursive resolver and thus obscure them from some network observers and from the user's Internet service provider. However, these systems merely transfer trust to a third party. We posit that argue that no single party should be able to associate DNS queries with a client IP address that issues those queries. To this end, this document specifies Oblivious DNS (ODNS), which introduces an additional layer of obfuscation between clients and their queries. To accomplish this, ODNS uses its own authoritative namespace; the authoritative servers for the ODNS namespace act as recursive resolvers for the DNS queries that they receive, but they never see the IP addresses for the clients that initiated these queries. The ODNS experimental protocol is compatible with existing DNS infrastructure.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Recognizing the privacy vulnerabilities associated with DNS queries, a number of standards have been developed and services deployed that that encrypt a user’s DNS queries to the recursive resolver and thus obscure them from some network observers and from the user's Internet service provider. However, these systems merely transfer trust to a third party. We posit that argue that no single party should be able to associate DNS queries with a client IP address that issues those queries [many of the Informative References can go here].

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.
Privacy terminology is as described in Section 3 of .
DNS terminology is as described in with one modification: we use the definition of Privacy-enabling DNS server taken from :

section.title: IANA considerations
section.t: For initial experimental deployment of this protocol, the name obliviousdns.com has been registered. Its length is a drawback, for the reasons discussed in and a shorter privately registered name may be chosen for future larger-scale experimentation. An infrastructure related zone would be more advantageous choice. Therefore discussion should resolve the appropriateness and conditions of a request for a special use domain name, e.g. odns.arpa. This falls under the considerations in . Notes: because of restrictions on TLD registration, following the example of .onion is infeasible. Traffic for ODNS traverses normal Internet paths, therefore the IANA special use registry recently established for Locally-Served DNS Zones, in which home.arpa has recently been registered , is also not a model for IANA considerations for the ODNS Namespace.

section.title: Security considerations
section.t: TODO (some questions to consider): what are residual risks in the ODNS scheme and additional mitigations? Is there any increase in attack surface for the users and operators in ODNS? Are systems depending on ODNS vulnerable to DoS in specific ways that should be mitigated?
